present_illness: ___ history w/ PMH of HTN and autism who presents as a transfer  from OSH s/p cardiac arrest. He reportedly had 2 days of  lethargy and malaise and diarrhea at home. He had an episode of  syncope at home when walking down the stairs (SOB prior per  mother). When EMS arrived, pt was agitated but awake but became  unresponsive and was pulseless on arrival to the ___ ED.  For PEA arrest, he received CPR, atropine, and epi with ROSC. He  then became hypotensive w/asystole received Ca, bicarb, epi, and  CPR. Also had episode of VTACH s/p shock in OSH. OSH labs were  notable for eo's of 5.8 on diff, lactate 9.4, INR 1.75, Cr 8.2,  and FSBG of 58. He had a right femoral CVL placed, received 3L  of fluid, and was uptitrated to 3 pressors of levo/epi/neo. He  received no abx, 1 amp of glucose, and was transferred to ___  for further management.  He arrived to ___ on max does of norepi, epi and phenylephrine  gtts. He was unresponsive but s/p NMB (rocuronium at 11:30 AM)  en route via Medflight. His labs were notable for WBC 24.0 (12%  bands), H/H 11.9/36.0, PLT 31, INR 1.3, BUN/Cr 83/8.3, ALT 114,  AST 143, CK 5097, AP 337, TB 5.4, Lipase 61, CK MB 20, Uric acid  17.7, Phos 8.3, calcium 7.4, Cortisol 66.9, negative UA,  negative serum and urine tox screens. His initial blood gas was  7.00/___/72. Lactate was 4.0 and free Ca was 1.01. Blood and  urine cultures were sent. Imaging was notable for CXR with  pulmonary edema, CT head with no acute bleed but subtle  subcortical white matter hypodensity in the right frontal lobe,  CT c-spine without acute fracture, and CTA chest and abdomen  with no PE, type I choledochal cyst, 3.5 cm heterogeneous,  potentially enhancing left renal lesion concerning for neoplasm,  and ill-defined segment VII with hypodense liver lesion. A  bedside echo showed a hyperdynamic heart. He received 150  bicarb, vanc/zosyn, tamiflu, azithromycin, and was loaded with  amiodarone for persistent tachycardia and AF. He was  temperature-controlled for normothermia and reached 37oc by 3:40  ___. He was admitted to the MICU for further management.  On admission to the MICU, the patient's VS were: . He was noted  to be in AF with RVR. In speaking with the patient's mother, the  patient only takes medications given to him by her. His only  regular medications are atenolol and protonix. He takes  indomethacin and colchicine as needed, and last dose was 5 days  ago. Because of not feeling well over the past few days, his  mother reported that the patient took 2 capsules of keflex  yesterday, but was not taking a prescribed antibiotic course.      Past Medical History: Autism   HTN ?Gout      Social History: ___ Family History:  No known history of sudden cardiac death.

radiology:
Report: EXAMINATION:
AP chest x-ray.

TECHNIQUE:
Supine AP chest radiograph.

FINDINGS:
An ET tube is seen with distal tip projecting 6 cm above the carina, in
appropriate position.  An enteric tube is seen coursing inferiorly, with
distal tip projecting over the expected position of stomach fundus.

There are low lung volumes. A widened mediastinum may reflect low lung volumes
and supine positioning. Pulmonary vascular engorgement and diffuse airspace
opacities likely relates to pulmonary vascular congestion and mild pulmonary
edema in the setting of volume resuscitation. Linear opacities in the
bilateral lower lungs likely represents bibasilar atelectasis. There is no
pneumothorax or pleural effusion.
Modality: Radiograph
Region: Chest
Exam Name: CHEST (PORTABLE AP)
Note ID: 10004235-RR-14

Report: EXAMINATION:
CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST:

TECHNIQUE:
Contiguous axial images images of the brain were obtained without
contrast. Coronal and sagittal as well as thin bone-algorithm reconstructed
images were obtained.

DOSE:
DLP:  1003 mGy-cm

CTDI:
55 mGy

FINDINGS:
There is no evidence of acute large vascular territorial infarction,
hemorrhage, edema, or mass. The ventricles and sulci are normal in size and
configuration. Gray and white matter differentiation is preserved.  There may
be subtle subcortical hypodensity within the right frontal lobe (02:24). 
Basal cisterns are patent.

No osseous abnormalities seen.  Minimal mucosal thickening is seen within the
sphenoid sinuses and left ethmoid air cells, as well as minimal opacification
of the left inferior mastoid air cells, findings which can suggest ongoing
inflammation. Secretions are noted within the nasopharynx, likely related to
recent intubation.
Modality: CT
Region: Head
Exam Name: CT HEAD W/O CONTRAST
Note ID: 10004235-RR-15

Report: EXAMINATION:
CT C-SPINE W/O CONTRAST:

TECHNIQUE:
Contiguous axial images were obtained.  Sagittal and coronal
reformatted images were generated.  No contrast was administered.

CTDIvol:  37 mGy

DLP:
847 mGy-cm

FINDINGS:
There is no acute fracture or malalignment. Vertebral body heights and
intervertebral disc spaces are maintained. No significant degenerative changes
are noted. Visualized outline of this thecal sac is grossly unremarkable.
There is no prevertebral soft tissue swelling. The left thyroid gland is
heterogeneous with punctate calcification, suggestive of underlying thyroid
goiter.

Smooth septal thickening within the lung apices suggests mild volume overload.
Endotracheal and orogastric tubes are noted within the trachea and esophagus
respectively.
Modality: CT
Region: Spine
Exam Name: CT C-SPINE W/O CONTRAST
Note ID: 10004235-RR-16

Report: EXAMINATION:
CTA CHEST, CT ABDOMEN, AND PELVIS:

TECHNIQUE:
Multidetector CT through the chest, abdomen, and pelvis was
performed following IV contrast administration with multiplanar reformations
provided. Oral contrast was not administered.

FINDINGS:


CHEST CTA:
The aorta and main thoracic great vessels are well-opacified. The
aorta demonstrates normal caliber without evidence of intramural hematoma or
dissection. The partially-imaged aortic arch branches are normal.  The main,
right, and left pulmonary arteries are well-opacified. There is no evidence of
lobar or segmental intraluminal filling defect.  The distal segmental and
subsegmental pulmonary arterial branches are not well visualized. There is no
arteriovenous malformation.

CHEST:
A heterogeneous, predominantly hypodense lesion within the left thyroid lobe
is only partially imaged. The heart and pericardium are within normal limits. 
There is no pericardial effusion.  There is no mediastinal, supraclavicular,
or axillary lymphadenopathy.  An ET tube is seen within the trachea, with
distal tip terminating 5 cm above the carina.  An enteric tube is seen within
the esophagus, which is otherwise normal.

Lung windows demonstrate interlobular septal thickening and mild ground-glass
opacities most conspicuous in the lung apices, consistent with mild pulmonary
edema.  There is bibasilar atelectasis. Otherwise, the imaged lungs are clear.

ABDOMEN:
An ill-defined hypodensity in segment VII of the liver is not
well-characterized.  Attention of follow-up imaging.  Otherwise, the liver
enhances homogeneously without concerning focal lesion. There is no
intrahepatic biliary ductal dilation. The portal vein is patent.  There is
fusiform dilation of the extrahepatic common hepatic and common bile duct and
the cystic duct measuring up to 53 mm, compatible with a Type I choledochal
cyst. Anti-dependent hyperdense material within the gallbladder lumen may
represent sludge, however, underlying mass lesion is also of concern given
choledochal cyst.

The pancreas enhances homogeneously without peripancreatic stranding or ductal
dilation. There is no splenomegaly or focal splenic lesion. The adrenal glands
are normal bilaterally.

A 3.5 cm heterogeneous, potentially enhancing lesion arises from the left
renal cortex, and demonstrates a mildly thickened hyperdense, likely enhancing
peripheral wall, concerning for neoplasm.  The ipsilateral renal vein is
patent.  Smaller hypodensities within the left renal cortex are too small to
characterize. Otherwise, the kidneys enhance and excrete symmetrically without
evidence of hydronephrosis.

An enteric tube terminates in the stomach fundus, which is normal appearing.
Small bowel loops are relatively decompressed, without evidence of wall
thickening or obstruction. The colon is unremarkable. The appendix is normal.
The abdominal aorta is normal in course and caliber with widely patent major
branches. There is no retroperitoneal hematoma or lymphadenopathy. No free air
or free fluid is seen.

PELVIS:
A right femoral central line is identified. A Foley catheter is seen
within a decompressed bladder. There is a rectal tube/catheter. Otherwise, the
imaged pelvic organs are unremarkable. There is no pelvic sidewall or inguinal
lymphadenopathy.

MUSCULOSKELETAL:
The imaged thoracolumbar spine demonstrates normal alignment. 
Horizontally-oriented buckling of the anterior cortex of the upper sternum is
suspicious for non-displaced fracture. There is no concerning osteolytic or
osteosclerotic lesion identified.
Modality: CT
Region: Chest
Exam Name: CTA CHEST W&W/O C&RECONS, NON-CORONARY
Note ID: 10004235-RR-17

Report: TECHNIQUE:
Single semi-upright AP view of the chest.

FINDINGS:
The endotracheal tube is positioned high, approximately 7 cm from the carina.
An enteric tube courses below the diaphragm with the tip out of the field of
view. The lung volumes are low. Bibasilar atelectasis is unchanged. Since the
prior exam, there has been a slight interval worsening of the vascular
congestion and mild pulmonary edema. There is no opacity to suggest pneumonia.
No pleural effusion or pneumothorax is identified. Widening of the mediastinal
contours is unchanged, and likely due to mediastinal fat, as seen on the prior
CT. The heart appears slightly larger.
Modality: Radiograph
Region: Chest
Exam Name: CHEST (PORTABLE AP)

CHEST (PORTABLE AP):

FINDINGS:
Compared to the prior study, the right IJ line may have been exchanged. The
tip overlies the proximal SVC. The ET tube, left IJ line and NG type tube
appear unchanged. No pneumothorax is detected.

There is some new subtle confluent opacity in the right perihilar region.
Otherwise, I doubt significant interval change. Prominent cardiomediastinal
silhouette is unchanged. Upper zone redistribution and diffuse vascular
blurring is similar to the prior film, allowing for technique. Increased
retrocardiac density with air bronchograms is also unchanged. No gross
effusion.

radiology:
Report: TYPE OF THE EXAM:
CT of the abdomen and pelvis.

TECHNIQUE:
Multiple axial MDCT images through the abdomen and pelvis were
obtained post-administration of intravenous contrast.  Coronal and sagittal
reconstructions were obtained.

FINDINGS:
Lung bases: There are bilateral small pleural effusion and thickened fissures,
suggestive of fluid overload.

There is evidence of recent  PTBD with placement of a left and right biliary 
external-internal drain with distal ends in  the third portion of the
duodenum.  The biliary drains travel through a CBD  metallic stent. There is
minimal residual intrahepatic biliary dilatation, notably in segments 3  5 and
8.  

There are no discrete lesions within the liver to suggest liver metastasis or
bile lakes.  There is irregularity surrounding the gallbladder fundus, which
is likely reactive edema. 

Evaluation of the pancreas demonstrates no evidence of abnormal masses.  There
is no gross lymphadenopathy in the porta hepatis or in the peripancreatic
region.  

Vascular structures are patent, including splenic vein, portal confluence, and
intrahepatic portal vein branches.  Spleen, bilateral kidneys and adrenal
glands are unremarkable in appearance.  There is overall anasarca and
mesenteric edema.

PELVIS:
There is moderate amount of  fluid within the pelvis with thin layer
of dependent hematocrit level.  There is no frank adenopathy.  There is
scattered diverticulosis without diverticulitis.

VASCULAR STRUCTURES:
There are scattered atherosclerotic calcifications of
the abdominal aortic vessels, without aneurysmal dilatation or dissection.

OSSEOUS STRUCTURES:
There is no evidence of destructive lytic lesions or
acute fractures.
Modality: CT
Region: Abdomen
Exam Name: CT ABD & PELVIS WITH CONTRAST
Note ID: 10060764-RR-13

Report: TYPE OF THE EXAM:
CT of the abdomen and pelvis.

TECHNIQUE:
Multiple axial MDCT images through the abdomen and pelvis were obtained
post-administration of intravenous contrast and ingestion of oral contrast.

LUNG BASES:
There are bilateral pleural effusions, small to moderate in size
with associated atelectasis.  No focal consolidation is seen.

ABDOMEN:
There are two percutaneously placed biliary anchor drains.  The
right catheter appears to have a straighter course compared to the prior CT,
post-revision.  The distal tip of the right catheter is seen extending to the
proximal end of the the metallic common bile duct stent which itself extends
into the right common hepatic duct.  The left-sided catheter is seen with
distal tip just proximal to the left-sided metal stent.  There is intermediate
attenuation material within the drains and stents.  This is often noted and
evaluation for luminal obstruction is limited.

There is mild nonspecific enhancement of the hepatic parenchyma surrounding
the right sided drain, possibly representing post procedural changes. Compared
to the prior study, there is development of a small to moderate amount of
perihepatic, subhepatic ascites and perisplenic ascites.  The gallbladder is
not abnormally distended. There is surrounding fluid.  There is small amount
of fluid in the left paracolic gutter which is slightly increased compared to
the prior study.  There is no significant lymphadenopathy within the abdomen
or pelvis.  The pancreas, kidneys, and adrenal glands are stable.  Kidneys
enhance homogeneously without abnormalities.

PELVIS:
There is a stable amount of fluid within the pelvis.  There are
numerous colonic diverticula.  No evidence of enlarged lymphadenopathy within
the pelvis.  There is minimal stranding along the right-sided colon which
probably is in the setting of anasarca.

Osseous structures are stable without evidence of worrisome blastic or lytic
lesions or acute fractures.

VASCULAR STRUCTURES:
Atherosclerotic plaques of the aorta and iliac vessels
are noted.  There is no aneurysmal dilatation or dissection.
Modality: CT
Region: Abdomen
Exam Name: CT ABD & PELVIS WITH CONTRAST
Note ID: 10060764-RR-17
discharge_diagnosis:
Cholangitis
E Coli and Enterococcal Septicemia
Cholangiocarcinoma

radiology:
Report: TECHNIQUE:
Single frontal chest radiograph was obtained portably with the
patient in an upright position.

FINDINGS:
Linear opacity at the right base likely represents atelectasis.  No
consolidation, pleural effusion, pneumothorax, or pulmonary edema is detected
on this single view.  Heart and mediastinal contours are stable.  Patulous
esophagus is again noted.
Modality: Radiograph
Region: Chest

Note ID: 10080928-RR-65

Report: TECHNIQUE:
MDCT images were obtained through the chest, abdomen and pelvis
following the administration of IV contrast.

FINDINGS:


CHEST:
There is no axillary, mediastinal, or hilar lymphadenopathy.  The
aorta is normal in caliber.  There are no filling defects in the pulmonary
artery to the subsegmental level.  The airways are patent to the subsegmental
level.  The esophagus appears normal.  There is no pleural effusion or
pneumothorax.  The heart and pericardium are unremarkable.  There are coronary
artery calcifications.  There is streaky atelectasis at the lung bases.  No
focal consolidation is seen.  There is a 5 mm nodule seen in the right middle
lobe, similar to study on ___.  A subpleural nodule is seen
measuring 4 mm (2, 50), similar to ___.

ABDOMEN:
A calcified granuloma is seen in the liver, similar to prior study. 
There is perfusion anomaly in the posterior right lobe.  There is significant
intrahepatic biliary duct dilatation, mainly involving the left lobe.  There
is significant dilation of the common bile duct measuring up to 1.5 cm in
diameter.  The gallbladder is significantly distended with cholelithiasis. 
There is no evidence of bowel wall thickening or pericholecystic fluid.  The
pancreas is unremarkable.  The spleen is normal.  There is a 1.3 cm cyst in
the upper pole of the left kidney.  Otherwise, the kidneys are unremarkable. 
There is no hydronephrosis.  There is no mesenteric or retroperitoneal
lymphadenopathy.  The pancreatic duct is dilated.

The stomach appears normal.  There are dilated loops of small and large bowel,
indicating possible ileus.  There is no evidence of obstruction.

PELVIS:
The bladder and terminal ureters are unremarkable.  Prostate and
seminal vesicles are normal.  The rectum is unremarkable.  There is no free
fluid in the pelvis.  There is no pelvic or inguinal lymphadenopathy.

CTA:
The intra-abdominal vasculature is patent.  There are scattered aortic
calcifications.  There are no aneurysms identified.  No evidence of
dissection.

The celiac artery and its major branches are patent.  SMA and its major
branches are patent.  Some calcifications of the splenic artery.  The ___ is
patent.
